dataset.title: Effects on Wildlife of Herbicide-induced Habitat Change, Tahoe National Forest, CA

creator.organizationName: University of California Natural Reserve System

abstract.para: MASTERS THESIS: The present study was designed to compare vegetation and animal populations on a plot sprayed with herbicides (Phenoxy herbicide 2,4, 5-T)six years previously with a similar unsprayed plot. Populations of birds, small mammals and deer were censused. This pilot study, involving only two plots without replications, was intended only to ascertain whether differences exist in animal populations that might relate to herbicide-induced changes in vegetation.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: The study area is situated in the Sagehen Creek basin on the east slope of the Sierra Nevada County. Two areas, each of approximately 4.5 ha, were selected.

section.title: Methods
section.para: VEGETATION: Vegetation was sampled at intervals along ten 30 m line transects (relative density, relative dominance and relative frequency).
BIRDS: The Williams spot map technique, as described by Williams (1936) and Bock and Lynch (1970), was used to estimate densities of the birds nesting or regularly feeding on the plots.

SMALL MAMMALS: Mark-recapture trapping was used to census the small mammal populations. Toe-clipping was used for animal identification... and information was recorded... included the grid number, the animal's number, its weight, sex, approximate age, and reproductive condition.
MULE DEER: Relative dder use was measured by means of pellet group counts.Ten 30m transects were walked, and pellet groups occurring within 1m on each side of the tape were counted.

description.para: BIRDS: Censusing was initiate in the early part of June and ended in July when birds were beginning to flock. MULE DEER: The counts were conducted during the middle of the summer and in early November.

samplingDescription.para: VEGETATION: The starting points were arbitrarily chosen from among grid points, and the directions of the transects were random.
